title: Problem Overview
content: Erdős Problem #144: Does the density of integers with close divisors (d₁ < d₂ < 2d₁) equal 1? SOLVED by Maier-Tenenbaum (1984). The threshold β* = log 3 - 1 separates density 1 from density 0 in the refined version.

title: Natural Density
content: The natural density d(A) = lim |A ∩ {1,...,n}| / n measures the 'proportion' of integers in A. For close divisors, density 1 means almost all integers have this property.

title: Close Divisors Property
content: An integer n has 'close divisors' if divisors d₁ < d₂ exist with d₂ < 2d₁. This means two divisors are within a factor of 2. Example: 6 has divisors 2, 3 with 3 < 2·2 = 4.

title: c-Close Divisors
content: The generalization: for any c > 1, n has c-close divisors if d₂ < c·d₁ for some divisors d₁ < d₂. The theorem holds for ALL c > 1, not just c = 2.

title: Main Conjecture
content: erdos_144_conjecture: The density of integers with close divisors equals 1. This was the original question - do 'almost all' integers have such divisors?

title: Maier-Tenenbaum Theorem
content: The definitive answer: YES, density equals 1. Maier and Tenenbaum proved this in 1984, earning reportedly $650 (more than the $250 prize) for solving both versions.

title: Critical Exponent
content: β* = log 3 - 1 ≈ 0.0986 is the magic threshold. For divisors d₂ < d₁(1 + (log n)^{-β}), density is 1 when β < β* and 0 when β > β*. A beautiful phase transition!

title: Refined Close Divisors
content: The refined version: n has (β)-close divisors if d₂ < d₁(1 + (log n)^{-β}). This allows studying increasingly tight divisor ratios as n grows.

title: Erdős-Hall Theorem
content: For β > log 3 - 1, the density of (β)-close divisors equals 0. Erdős and Hall (1979) proved this complementary result, establishing one half of the phase transition.

title: Maier-Tenenbaum Refined
content: For β < log 3 - 1, density equals 1. This completes the picture: divisors can get arbitrarily close (relative to log n) for almost all integers, up to the threshold β*.

title: Phase Transition
content: The density jumps discontinuously from 0 to 1 at β* = log 3 - 1. This is a sharp threshold - there's no intermediate behavior.

title: Prime Powers Fail
content: Prime powers p^k have divisors 1, p, p², ..., p^k. Consecutive divisors differ by factor p ≥ 2, so NO prime power has close divisors. They form the 'exceptional' set of density 0.

title: Example: 6
content: 6 = 2·3 has divisors 1, 2, 3, 6. Check: 2 < 3 < 4 = 2·2. So d₁ = 2, d₂ = 3 works! The multiple prime factors create clustering.

title: Intuition: Lumpy Integers
content: Most integers have many prime factors (by Erdős-Kac, ~log log n on average). More prime factors means more divisors, which tend to cluster. 'Generic' integers are 'lumpy' with close divisors.

title: Erdős's Retracted Claim
content: In 1964, Erdős claimed a proof for β < log 3 - 1 giving density 1. The proof was flawed and retracted in 1979. This shows even Erdős made mistakes - but his conjecture was ultimately correct!

title: Divisor Distribution
content: The proof exploits how divisors of typical integers distribute. Most divisors cluster around √n, creating many opportunities for close pairs. This is a key insight from multiplicative number theory.

title: Erdős-Kac Connection
content: The Erdős-Kac theorem: ω(n) (number of prime factors) is approximately normally distributed with mean and variance log log n. This explains why 'typical' integers have many factors and thus close divisors.

title: Final Status
content: erdos_144_status: Both the basic conjecture (c = 2) and strong version (any c > 1) are proven. Maier-Tenenbaum completely resolved this $250 problem, revealing the beautiful phase transition at β* = log 3 - 1.
